1.00.text:
I'm Phillip Allott, Professor Emeritus of
International Public Law, in Cambridge University.

7.07.text:
There has never been a better time to be an
international lawyer. International Law is

13.30.text:
at last emerging as a sophisticated legal
system, in an international society experiencing

21.51.text:
take-off - to borrow two metaphors from development
economics.

27.63.text:
International Law is living its own 1860's.
From the 1860's, especially in European countries

35.29.text:
and the United States, the forms of law multiplied
prolifically to respond to the vastly greater

43.30.text:
complexity and energy of society. Legal fragmentation
and institutional innovation were an expression

51.96.text:
of self-transforming social vitality - as
they are now in the emerging international

58.94.text:
society.
International lawyers are the most privileged

63.99.text:
of all lawyers. International Law is the law
of all laws, the law of the whole human world.

73.42.text:
International lawyers are front and centre
in the drama of making the new international

79.42.text:
society.
But there's something that greatly limits

84.76.text:
the part we can play in the project of making
the law of the new international society.

92.65.text:
The international world suffers from a grotesque
poverty of philosophy. That phrase - 'poverty

99.23.text:
of philosophy'- was used by Karl Marx in 1847
to criticise the situation at the level of

107.58.text:
national society.
Our predecessors at the national level had

112.76.text:
the great advantage that they could use thirty
centuries of intense thought about the forms

119.81.text:
of law and order required for the good life
lived in a good society.

126.93.text:
The grotesque poverty of philosophy at the
international level means that the international

132.46.text:
world has one big idea. Everything else is
a deduction from that one big idea.

140.90.text:
The one big idea is that the international
world is not a social phenomenon but an anomalous

148.70.text:
excrescence from national societies, an exogenous
unsocial dependent reality, isolated from

157.81.text:
the vast intellectual superstructure required
for the survival and prospering of national

164.28.text:
society.
Re-imagining the one big idea of the international

169.92.text:
world is an exciting challenge for those of
us who think for a living. It is an exciting

176.05.text:
challenge for international lawyers. And it
is a particularly delightful challenge for

181.25.text:
those of us who are philosophical idealists.
Idealism, like relativity, comes in two forms

189.44.text:
- general idealism and special idealism.
General idealism recognises that reality is

197.80.text:
made from ideas. The whole of science, the
whole of society, the whole of law - all of

204.16.text:
them are nothing but a fabrication of thinking,
to echo the Japanese idealist philosopher

210.80.text:
Nishida Kitaro. And what the mind has made
the mind can change.

217.44.text:
Special idealism recognises that the mind
contains a particular kind of idea - the ideal

224.25.text:
- a powerful form of mental energy that leads
us to make a better reality, caused by the

231.73.text:
magnetic attraction of ideas such as justice,
the good, the true, the beautiful, the ideal...

241.50.text:
In George Bernard Shaw's play The Doctor's
Dilemma, written in 1906, the doctor had invented

247.80.text:
a cure for a life-threatening disease. How
should he choose the people whose lives he

254.77.text:
would save?
The idealist's dilemma is also about curing

259.88.text:
disease and saving lives. But it's more complex.
The idealist's dilemma is three dilemmas.

268.31.text:
Should we simply give up, and admit defeat?
Who should we talk to? Should we tell the

274.78.text:
truth about the real state of the world?
So - the first dilemma. Should we idealists

282.28.text:
simply give up, go off and cultivate our gardens?
It's certainly tempting. Look at human history.

290.96.text:
The good done by good ideas has often been
undone by bad ideas.

295.14.text:
The high civilisations of ancient Greece and
Rome were compatible with incidental barbarism.

302.78.text:
The Emperor Constantine's legitimising of
Christianity led to the politicising of a

311.18.text:
deeply unpolitical religion.
The American social ideal of the 'city on

317.04.text:
a hill' contains an idea of 'exceptionalism'
which has proved anti-social in relation to

325.06.text:
the rest of the world.
Europe's idea of its cultural superiority

331.20.text:
fuelled an imperialism in which others paid
a high price to acquire its incidental benefits.

340.44.text:
Revolutions have often been negated by reaction,
sometimes replacing a bad social order with

348.58.text:
something even worse.
The ideal of self-determination opened the

354.39.text:
way for new tyrannies and corrupt oligarchies
and failing states.

360.12.text:
The ideal of freedom has produced the extreme
unfreedom of modern democratic-capitalist-technocratic

368.50.text:
society.
We must also remember certain notorious tyrants

373.96.text:
when we think of the great world-changing
ideas of Hobbes and Rousseau and Marx and

380.37.text:
Nietzsche.
Then there is Emmerich de Vattel, the brilliant

384.41.text:
18th-century rationaliser of the one big international
idea, proposing an international legal system

392.01.text:
appropriate for the newly emerging nation-states.
We've lived the Vattelian idea-system for

400.13.text:
two hundred turbulent years.
Idealists have a special interest in the phenomenon

407.20.text:
of social change, because social change contains
a change in dominant socialised ideas.

416.39.text:
We might even identify - tentatively - three
Isaac-Newton-style Laws of Social Change.

425.24.text:
Law I. Inertia favours the past over the future.
You preserve the social institutions in form,

434.39.text:
but transform their functions - for example,
the British monarchy.

439.52.text:
Law II. Exceptional change requires exceptional
energy. Social change is normally linear in

451.30.text:
a chaotic sort of way, unless some exceptional
social force intervenes, such as the forms

459.30.text:
of social collapse known as war and revolution
or the intervention of the kind of people

465.32.text:
Hegel calls world-historical figures - an
Alexander or a Napoleon or the founder of

475.26.text:
a religion.
Law III. Exceptional change generates a countervailing

480.23.text:
force of resistance to social change. It is
remarkable how often the old class power-structure

489.05.text:
survives a revolution, perhaps stronger than
ever, borrowing some of the new ideas.

497.37.text:
But idealists don't give up, don't throw in
the towel.

501.18.text:
Why? Idealists are realistic utopians. We
know all about the duality of the human being

509.92.text:
- capable of self-harming and self-destroying
- capable of self-surpassing and self-perfecting

519.61.text:
The great utopian thinkers were perfectly
familiar with the dark side of the human condition,

526.20.text:
but they were also optimists about the possibility
of a better world - Plato, Pico della Mirandola,

534.43.text:
Thomas More, Bacon, Vico, Rousseau.
Contrast them with so-called dystopian thinkers

542.31.text:
who insist on extrapolating from the dark
side of the human condition.

548.26.text:
Someone has to do the heavy thinking of human
self-perfecting and self-evolving. And that

553.10.text:
is the job of us idealists.
So - the second dilemma - who should the idealist

561.26.text:
speak to?
People who regard themselves as practical

565.74.text:
people, involved in what they call the real
world, are impatient with those of us who

571.87.text:
specialise in thinking about that real world.
Such people include many legal practitioners.

579.88.text:
They have a Manichean view: practice good,
theory bad.

586.43.text:
And yet Vattel's theory was welcomed and admired
by kings and politicians and diplomats - perhaps

593.93.text:
because his theory rationalises and justifies
their bizarre behaviour.

600.19.text:
Kark Marx and Antonio Gramsci were right to
identify the cultural hegemony of the ruling

608.17.text:
class. Those who have most social power have
most power over the formation of a society's

615.86.text:
ideas. And that has certainly been true in
International Law.

622.72.text:
What Marx and Gramsci underestimated was the
propensity of the ruling class to disagree

629.49.text:
within itself. The ruling classes of earlier
centuries were seething cauldrons of disagreement

636.67.text:
about everything. From the existence and personal
attributes of God to the most elegant cut

644.22.text:
of a gentleman's doublet. From when to grow
turnips to the educability of the toiling

650.75.text:
masses.
'I am a human being, and nothing human is

655.89.text:
alien to me.' That wonderful saying from a
play by the Roman playwright Terence (Heauton

662.83.text:
Timorumenos) was the state-of-mind of the
old educated ruling classes, our predecessors-in-office.

671.16.text:
They knew that critical and creative thinking
can change the world, can make a better world.

677.79.text:
So, we idealists don't need to address any
audience in particular. We must say urbi et

684.95.text:
orbi what we have to say and keep on saying
it.

690.48.text:
Public thinkers are megaphones of the mind.
The future will hear us. And the future will

696.36.text:
decide what to do with what we've said.
So then there is the idealist's third dilemma.

704.92.text:
What should we say? Should we tell the truth,
the whole truth, about the state of the world

711.05.text:
as it is?
That is the most painful of the idealist's

715.46.text:
dilemmas. Even at this moment, it inhibits
me from saying all that should be said.

722.93.text:
'To tell the truth is revolutionary.' That
was a saying of Ferdinand Lassalle, the founder

730.26.text:
of German socialism.
'High over roaring Temple-bar, we must look

737.89.text:
at all things as they are.' That is from a
poem by Alfred Tennyson, contemplating the

745.86.text:
chaotic and troubling reality of nineteenth-century
London.

752.03.text:
The bourgeois hero of a play by Molière,
the seventeenth-century French playwright,

758.26.text:
was trying to make himself into a gentleman.
He was pleased and proud to learn that he

764.97.text:
had always spoken in prose, without knowing
it - which obviously meant that he was not

771.35.text:
far from being a poet.
People who think that they're practical people

777.04.text:
speak theory in everything they say and do,
every day of their lives, even if they don't

784.24.text:
know what the theory is, or where it came
from.

789.22.text:
The philosopher Julia Kristeva speaks of our
life as a form of writing. To live is to write

797.95.text:
the story of our living. Each one of us - each
society - is a work of fiction - a story with

805.27.text:
a huge back-story in human history and in
our minds.

811.44.text:
Thinkers such as Vico and Husserl and Freud,
among very many others, have studied the vast

816.91.text:
accumulation of ideas in our societies and
in our minds that determine our view of ourselves

823.75.text:
and our view of the world.
Nation and state and government are notorious

830.55.text:
fictions, metaphysical entities existing only
in and for the human mind.

837.92.text:
The whole of the law is a vast work of fiction,
a masterpiece of the human imagination, creating

845.04.text:
its own entirely artificial reality. Lawyers
- even practising lawyers - are creative writers,

853.70.text:
re-inventing the story of the law every day.
The French philosopher Jean-Paul Sartre diagnosed

861.98.text:
a psychological condition that he called bad
faith - lying to ourselves. Bad faith causes

870.80.text:
the existential anxiety - the Angst - of our
everyday lives.

877.38.text:
International lawyers should be especially
troubled by Angst. The international world

882.74.text:
is a world of ultimate bad faith - in which
humanity lies to itself about itself.

890.18.text:
The big lie of the international world is
the suppressing of an unbearable truth. The

898.44.text:
big truth that we repress is this:
We have inherited a world order that is a

904.88.text:
fundamental world disorder, causing one disaster
after another, shaming the humanity of the

914.56.text:
human species.
It's a world disorder of states - those random

919.88.text:
by-products of the chaos of history, artificial
amalgams of lands and tribes.

926.80.text:
It's a world of governments, some of them
no better than criminal conspiracies, still

933.49.text:
playing the games of diplomacy and war that
kings and tyrants have always played.

940.30.text:
War is savage insanity. Those are the words
of the sixteenth-century Dutch philosopher

946.36.text:
Erasmus. And yet we rationalise war. We even
justify war.

952.67.text:
And now we're living at a time when a pandemic
of violence is plaguing the world in religious

958.76.text:
and ethnic conflicts, causing horror and terror
and squalor and misery and suffering to countless

966.95.text:
innocent human beings.
James Cahill has suggested that the whole

972.08.text:
world now seems to be a battlefield of overt
and covert war. The insanity of the human

980.21.text:
species.
We often refer to the distribution of social

985.47.text:
power in a society as its class-system.
In the emerging international society, there

992.72.text:
is an emerging global class-system.
There is a vast international bureaucracy

999.68.text:
accountable to no one - a bureaucracy of the
kind analysed by Max Weber, purporting to

1008.04.text:
govern rationally, rather than politically.
There is an aristocracy of globalised wealth

1015.66.text:
and ultimate economic power, owing social
allegiance to no national society.

1022.54.text:
There are the masters of globalised science
and technology, beyond social and moral control.

1031.11.text:
There is a disempowered and dispirited global
middle class.

1036.13.text:
And there is a massive global underclass with
no present expectation of living a good life

1043.10.text:
in a good society.
We may hear echoes, in all this, of national

1050.17.text:
class-systems in Europe and the United States
at the beginning of the twentieth century.

1056.37.text:
And, all the while, human beings are becoming
alienated from their own humanity - in the

1063.43.text:
sense of that word discussed by thinkers such
as Rousseau, Marx and Marcuse.

1070.92.text:
Human beings are being dehumanised by suprahuman
collective systems and suprahuman technologies

1079.84.text:
- autonomic systems, self-governing, beyond
the control of actual human beings.

1089.08.text:
And yet the trending global philosophy is
whateverism. 'Whatever. Things are as they

1096.74.text:
are, and always will be.'
That is the latest version of a perennial

1102.98.text:
defeatist philosophy, stretching back to the
Sophists of ancient Greece and the many forms

1109.85.text:
of Hellenistic scepticism.
And then there is our relationship to the

1115.29.text:
planet where we live. The whole human future
depends on the well-being of the natural world.

1122.15.text:
But we organise our co-habitation with our
natural habitat by aggregating subordinate

1128.14.text:
interests, rather than by disaggregating the
common interest of humanity.

1135.91.text:
Disaggregating the common interest of society
is the function of law. Disaggregating the

1142.22.text:
common interest of humanity is the true function
of International Law - 'the advantage not

1150.39.text:
of particular states...but of the great society
of states' - to echo one of the founders of

1157.70.text:
modern International Law, Hugo Grotius, writing
in 1625.

1161.96.text:
So how do we find the common interest? That
is the function of politics.

1170.16.text:
Politics is an expression of society's life-force,
its impulse of life, as I call it in my own

1180.11.text:
work. Politics is an overwhelming and insatiable
desire for social change - the expressing

1188.02.text:
of a collective libido, to adopt another term
used by Julia Kristeva.

1194.40.text:
The Latin word libido is a central concept
of the mind-philosophy of Sigmund Freud, studying

1200.75.text:
the individual human mind. To extend the use
of the term to society - to speak of a collective

1207.45.text:
social libido is to describe a real phenomenon,
not merely to speak metaphorically.

1216.10.text:
Politicians channel the collective libido
- sometimes in more ways than one. People

1223.48.text:
sometimes call it 'the aphrodisiac of power'.
Substituting politics for diplomacy is a major

1232.04.text:
challenge in making the future of international
society.

1237.06.text:
Making bureaucratic internationalism politically
accountable is another major challenge in

1243.52.text:
making the future of international society.
We are familiar with a controversial provision

1251.32.text:
in Section 10 of the Articles of Agreement
of the World Bank.

1255.34.text:
'The [World] Bank and its officers shall not
interfere in the political affairs of any

1262.60.text:
member... Only economic considerations shall
be relevant to their decisions.'

1269.08.text:
As if there can be economic considerations
that are not political considerations.

1276.73.text:
Politics translates social values into judgments
of the common interest, which may then be

1282.00.text:
put into the universal form of law. Law is
then disaggregated and particularised and

1289.39.text:
applied, modifying real-world behaviour, reconciling
common interest and private interest.

1298.27.text:
When we give effect to the law, we may do
so out of self-interest. But, in so doing,

1305.02.text:
we also act as agents of the common interest
of society

1309.39.text:
That is the wonder and the magic of law. The
unfreedom of the law can give us the freedom

1318.39.text:
to lead a better life in better societies
- as Rousseau so brilliantly observed.

1325.01.text:
At another time of revolutionary change - 1776
- the great Tom Paine had a charming Manichean

1332.85.text:
moment. He said that society is a blessing,
and government is a necessary evil.

1341.70.text:
What we call constitutionalism means using
social power to transcend governmental power,

1349.49.text:
using legal power to transcend legal power.
That is the great principle that we call the

1356.20.text:
Rule of Law.
It took many centuries of thought and experience

1362.51.text:
to articulate clearly the idea of constitutionalism
and to place it at the heart of the good life

1369.40.text:
in a good society.
There are two kinds of idealist revolutionary.

1375.86.text:
A conservative revolutionary wants to use
the best of the past to make a better future.

1384.38.text:
A socialist revolutionary wants to get rid
of the worst of the past to make a better

1390.32.text:
future.
Evolutionary constitutionalism is one of our

1395.35.text:
greatest inheritances from the past.
Installing the Rule of Law in international

1402.29.text:
society is a major challenge in making the
human future.

1407.66.text:
To use the idea of society in re-writing the
international story is to implant new philosophical

1417.19.text:
genetic material in the biology of international
society - a modification in the philosophical

1425.72.text:
genome of international society.
The transforming idea of society creates the

1433.16.text:
possibility of evolutionary constitutionalism
at the global level - giving practical effect

1440.61.text:
at last to 'the moral and political unity
of the human race'- to echo the words of the

1449.49.text:
Spanish writer Francisco Suárez, another
of the founders of modern International Law,

1457.40.text:
writing in 1612.
We must treat the diseases of the social mind

1463.55.text:
at every level, helping to sublimate humanity's
wild energy in making a better human world

1472.27.text:
at every level, from the family and the village
to the international society of the whole

1478.49.text:
human race, the society of all societies.
Our ultimate challenge in making a better

1486.61.text:
human future is to think the new and necessary
philosophy of all human existence. Cognitive

1496.34.text:
therapy for the human species.
The Irish poet Seamus Heaney said: 'Whatever

1506.58.text:
is given can always be re-imagined.' (Seeing
Things, 1991)

1511.07.text:
Re-imagining the international story is hard
work, without public reward or honours. And

1519.10.text:
it meets resistance. Vested interest in what-is
is the permanent and formidable enemy of what-might-be.

1530.46.text:
I'm going to end with a paean of joy and praise.
Remarkable things have happened during the

1537.57.text:
fifty years that I have been actively involved
in International Law.

1542.33.text:
There is the 1860's phenomenon that I mentioned
at the beginning - International Law as the

1550.30.text:
emerging legal system of an international
society experiencing take-off.

1556.69.text:
There is the great sophisticating of the study
of International Law over the last twenty-five

1564.08.text:
years.
But my praise and joy are directed especially

1569.02.text:
at the emergence of a large number of younger
intelligent and committed international lawyers.

1574.94.text:
A wonderful thing.
Old international lawyers are beyond reason

1580.80.text:
and beyond redemption. Younger international
lawyers can respect the social responsibility

1588.03.text:
that goes beyond our professional responsibilities.
Voltaire was a leading figure of the eighteenth-century

1595.90.text:
French Enlightenment - concealing his defiant
idealism behind a façade of scepticism and

1603.81.text:
despair.
In his novel Candide, Voltaire enjoyed making

1609.65.text:
fun of what he misunderstood of the rationalism
of the German idealist philosopher Leibniz.

1618.26.text:
But Voltaire's Candide can also be read as
a diatribe about the horrors caused by public

1625.90.text:
power.
In the famously ambiguous final pages of the

1629.81.text:
novel, Dr Pangloss doesn't admit defeat.
The Turkish wise-man had told him to stop

1638.15.text:
worrying about the horrors of the world.
But Pangloss persists: 'I was hoping that

1644.72.text:
I might reason with you a little about causes
and effects, about the best of possible worlds,

1651.82.text:
the origin of evil, the nature of the soul,
and the pre-established harmony.' (Actually,

1657.96.text:
those are favourite topics of us philosophical
idealists.)

1663.22.text:
And Voltaire himself didn't give up the struggle.
He did not go off and cultivate his own garden.

1669.60.text:
He went on arguing vehemently about everything,
until the day of his death.

1675.03.text:
A delightful ben trovato story is that, on
his deathbed, the priest asked him to renounce

1683.23.text:
Satan. Voltaire said: 'this is not the time
to be making enemies'.

1689.66.text:
Non-engagement is also engagement, as they
used to say in 1960's Paris. To translate

1695.75.text:
that into plain English: whateverism butters
no parsnips.

1702.31.text:
Echoing Antonio Gramsci again: we need a new
kind of fully engaged intellectual - able

1709.89.text:
to balance pessimism of the intellect with
an invincible optimism of the will in making

1717.39.text:
the human future. Pessimism of the intellect
- optimism of the will.

1724.54.text:
I'm more hopeful now than I have ever been
that International Law will have a better

1731.60.text:
future, playing its proper part in the making
of a radically better human world.

1736.46.text:
We idealists will not give up. We will speak
to anyone who will listen. We will tell the

1743.11.text:
truth.
The only power over power is the power of

1749.93.text:
ideas.
Idealists of the world, unite!

1755.11.text:
We will use the power of ideas to make a better
world!
